factoid: Count Ilyá Rostóv glances angrily at the author who went on reading his verses.
Count Ilyá Rostóv bows to Bagratión.
Everyone rose, feeling that dinner was more important than verses.
Bagratión, again preceding all the rest, went into dinner.
Bagratión was seated in the place of honor between two Alexanders—Bekleshëv and Narýshkin.
The seating arrangement between Bagratión and the two Alexanders was a significant allusion to the name of the sovereign.
Three hundred persons took their seats in the dining room.
Persons were seated according to their rank and importance.
More important persons sat nearer to the honored guest.
The seating arrangement followed the principle that water flows deepest where the land lies lowest.
Count Ilyá Rostóv presented his son to Bagratión.
Bagratión recognized the son.
Bagratión said a few words to the son.
Bagratión's words were disjointed and awkward.
Count Ilyá Rostóv looked joyfully and proudly around while Bagratión spoke to his son.
Nicholas Rostóv, Denísov, and Dólokhov sat almost at the middle of the table.
Pierre sat facing Nicholas Rostóv, Denísov, and Dólokhov.
Pierre sat beside Prince Nesvítski.
Count Ilyá Rostóv sat facing Bagratión.
The other members of the committee sat facing Bagratión.
Count Ilyá Rostóv did the honors to the prince.
Count Ilyá Rostóv's efforts were not in vain.
The dinner was splendid.
Count Ilyá Rostóv was not at ease until the end of the meal.
Count Ilyá Rostóv winked at the butler.
Count Ilyá Rostóv whispered directions to the footmen.
Count Ilyá Rostóv awaited each expected dish with anxiety.
Everything was excellent.
The footmen popped corks and filled champagne glasses.
After the fish, the count exchanged glances with the other committee members.
The count whispered that there will be many toasts and that it was time to begin.
The count rose.
All were silent, waiting for what the count would say.
The count cried 'To the health of our Sovereign, the Emperor!'.
The count's kindly eyes grew moist with tears of joy and enthusiasm.
The band struck up 'Conquest's joyful thunder waken...'.
All rose and cried 'Hurrah!'.
Bagratión rose and shouted 'Hurrah!' in the same voice he used on the field at Schön Grabern.
Young Rostóv's ecstatic voice could be heard above the three hundred others.
Young Rostóv nearly wept.
Young Rostóv roared 'To the health of our Sovereign, the Emperor! Hurrah!'.
Young Rostóv emptied his glass at one gulp and dashed it to the floor.
Many followed Young Rostóv's example.
The footmen cleared away the broken glass.
Everybody sat down again.
Everybody smiled at the noise they had made.
Everybody exchanged remarks.
The old Count Ilyá Rostóv rose once more.
The old Count Ilyá Rostóv glanced at a note lying beside his plate.
The old Count Ilyá Rostóv proposed a toast 'To the health of the hero of our last campaign, Prince Peter Ivánovich Bagratión!'.
The old Count Ilyá Rostóv's blue eyes grew moist.
Three hundred voices cried 'Hurrah!'.
A choir began singing a cantata composed by Paul Ivánovich Kutúzov.
After the singing, another toast was proposed.
Count Ilyá Rostóv became more and more moved.
More glass was smashed.
The shouting grew louder.
They drank to Bekleshëv.
They drank to Narýshkin.
They drank to Uvárov.
They drank to Dolgorúkov.
They drank to Apráksin.
They drank to Valúev.
They drank to the committee.
They drank to all the club members.
They drank to all the club guests.
They drank to Count Ilyá Rostóv separately as the organizer of the banquet.
The count took out his handkerchief.
The count covered his face.
The count wept outright.
Pierre sat opposite Dólokhov and Nicholas Rostóv.
Pierre ate and drank much, and eagerly.
Some great change had come over Pierre that day.
Pierre was silent all through dinner.
Pierre looked about.
Pierre blinked.
Pierre scowled.
Pierre had fixed eyes and a look of complete absent‑mindedness.
Pierre rubbed the bridge of his nose.
Pierre's face was depressed and gloomy.
Pierre seemed to see and hear nothing of what was going on around him.
Pierre was absorbed by some depressing and unsolved problem.
